title: Trump halts trade negotiations with Turkey and threatens to 'swiftly destroy' their economy
text:
Donald Trump says he plans on authorising fresh sanctions on Turkish officials and halting trade negotiations with the country, after Turkey's military began "destabilising actions" in northeast Syria.

The US president's statement came as the Turkish military continued its offensive against Kurdish fighters previously allied to the United States in the fight against Isis, potentially sparking destabilisation in the region after years of fierce fighting to subdue the terror group.

The offensive began after the US pulled its military presence from northeast Syria, giving Turkey the ability to attack the Kurdish fighters who had been a strong ally to American interests there.

"The United States will aggressively use economic sanctions to target those who enable, facilitate, and finance these heinous acts in Syria," the president said in a statement released by the White House and posted to Mr Trump's Twitter account.

"I am fully prepared to swiftly destroy Turkey's economy if Turkish leaders continue down this dangerous and destructive path."

He said he would "soon be issuing an executive order authorising the imposition of sanctions against current and former officials of the Government of Turkey and any persons contributing to Turkey's destabilising actions in northeast Syria", but did not say when this would happen.

However, he said negotiations for a $100 billion trade deal with Turkey would stop immediately.

Mr Trump has faced howls of opposition, notably from senior Republicans like Lindsey Graham, over his decision to withdraw from positions in northeast Syria. While he has addressed his reasons for doing so in tweets and speeches, the statement is his first formal effort at explaining his rationale.

Kurdish fighters who helped push back Isis as part of the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) have looked for new allies to push back against aggression from Turkey.

"You have given up on us. You are leaving us to be slaughtered," SDF general Mazloum Kobani Abdi told William Roebuck, the deputy special envoy to the global coalition to defeat Isis, during a meeting on Thursday. That conversation was detailed in an internal US government readout obtained by CNN.

"You are not willing to protect the people, but you do not want another force to come and protect us. You have sold us. This is immoral," he said.

Mr Trump's latest calls for sanctions on Turkey highlight the narrowing set of options available to the United States in the region, with the removal of forces there.

And, they fall in line with the president's general approach to foreign relations, with Mr Trump making heavy use of sanctions to try and force foreign adversaries and allies to bend to his will.

Monday's statement follows after several days in which American officials had positioned sanctions as the best path forward, after military options were ruled out.

The president's decision to begin new sanctions on Turkey come just after he claimed without evidence that Kurds may be "releasing" captured Isis fighters deliberately, with the intention of pulling the US into a military conflict there.

Mr Trump has ruled that out, however, and tweeted that he believes it would be a bad idea to go to war with Turkey, which is a fellow member of Nato.
